description: From Middle English selly, selly, sellich, from Old English sellīċ, seldlīċ (“rare, strange, wondrous, extraordinary, wonderful; having unusually good qualities, excellent, admirable; select, better, superior, choice”), from Proto-Germanic *seldalīkaz, equivalent to seld +‎ -ly. Cognate with Scots selly, silly (“approved, good, worthy”), Old Saxon seldlīk (“rare, wonderful”), Gothic 𐍃𐌹𐌻𐌳𐌰𐌻𐌴𐌹𐌺𐍃 (sildaleiks, “wonderful”).

adjectives.description: selly (comparative sellier or more selly, superlative selliest or most selly)

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) Rare; wonderful; admirable

adverbs.description: selly (comparative sellier or more selly, superlative selliest or most selly)

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) Wonderfully, wondrously.
examples: His brother was  […]  selly sick and sore unsound.

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) A marvel; wonder; something wonderful or rare
examples: The line is a masterstroke of noncommitment, for the event is a "selly" in the sight of some unidentified readers.
